beers.name: Irish Ale
beers.history: Also known as Bohemian Pilsners, Pilsner beer was first brewed back in the 1840's in Czechoslovakia, but nowadays you can find Belgian, German and American varieties. Pilsners are known to be extremely refreshing and easy to drink.

beers.name: Stouts & Porters
beers.history: After prohibition ended in America, large macro-breweries created these light-bodied, pale, fizzy lagers meant for mass-consumption and production. Favorite among college students and grumpy old men alike.
beers.malt: Basic, thin, typically using low cost cereal grains

beers.name: German Ale
beers.history: The Germans answer to the Czech Pilsner to keep up with demand in the 1800's. Very similar to the spicy hops of the Pilsner, but a bit more malty.
beers.malt: Basic, but enough to balance the hops

beers.name: Weisbeer
beers.history: Similar to the classic Czech pilsner, but with a good ol' 'MURICA twist. Expect a more bitter, malty and alcoholic beer.
beers.flavor: High alcohol content lends spicy notes, malty yet sweet

beers.name: English Pale Ale
beers.history: The Germans weren't the only ones who thought they needed a beer of their own in the 1800's. Inspired by the Czech Pilsners as well, but they tend to be more malt based and less bitter
beers.flavor: High alcohol content lends spicy notes, malty yet sweet
